title: 115_s2018
content: The "American Family Act of 2017" establishes a fully refundable Child Tax Credit by eliminating the existing credit and inserting a new section 36C in the Internal Revenue Code. The "American Family Act of 2017" introduces a Child Tax Credit allowing a credit for qualifying children based on their age and the taxpayer's income. The "American Family Act of 2017" introduces a Child Tax Credit based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeding certain threshold amounts for different filing statuses. The "American Family Act of 2017" introduces a Child Tax Credit based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeding certain threshold amounts for different filing statuses. The credit amount is determined by the number of qualifying children, with a maximum credit of $55,000 for married individuals filing separately. Marital status is determined under section 7703. A qualifying child is defined as a child under 19 years of age, as outlined in section 152(c) of the Act. The term 'qualifying child' refers to a child under 19 years of age as defined in section 152(c). Non-citizens are excluded from this definition. The $3,000 amount in subsection (a)(1) will be adjusted for inflation after 2017 based on the cost of living adjustment. The tax credit adjustment for the calendar year is based on the cost of living adjustment. Any increase not a multiple of $50 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. Taxpayers must include the name and taxpayer identification number of qualifying children on their tax return. No credit is allowed if the taxpayer's identifying number was issued after the due date for filing the return. The taxpayer identification number must be issued before the due date for filing the return to qualify for the tax credit. No credit is allowed if the identifying number is issued after the due date. Additionally, the taxable year must be a full 12 months, except in cases of a taxpayer's death. Taxpayers who improperly claimed credit in prior years face restrictions for up to 10 taxable years. Taxpayers who improperly claimed credit in prior years may face restrictions for up to 10 taxable years, depending on whether the claim was due to fraud or reckless/intentional disregard of rules. If denied credit due to deficiency procedures, no credit will be allowed under this section. Taxpayers denied credit due to deficiency procedures must provide necessary information to demonstrate eligibility for the credit in subsequent years. The amount of credit allowed for a taxable year will be reduced by any advance payments received, and excess advance payments may result in an increase in tax liability for that year. Excess advance payments under section 7527A will increase tax liability if they exceed the credit allowed for the taxable year. "SEC. 7527A. ADVANCE PAYMENT OF CHILD TAX CREDIT." The Secretary will establish a program for advance monthly payments of the child tax credit to eligible taxpayers, limited to the excess of the credit amount over estimated taxes for the year. The program for advance monthly payments of the child tax credit will make efforts to apply the limitation of section 36C(b) with respect to payments made under the program. Conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including changes to the table of sections for subpart A and subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of subtitle A. Sec. 36C. Child tax credit. Amended table of sections for chapter 77 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Sec. 7527A. Advance payment of child tax credit. Amendments made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding tax credits for children. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include changes to sections 6211, 6213, and 1324, with a focus on inserting references to section 36C. These amendments will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2016.
